identification.name: CEAP Classification for Chronic Venous Disease

definition.formal: The CEAP classification is a standardized descriptive system for chronic venous disorders that categorizes disease based on Clinical manifestations (C), Etiology (E), Anatomic distribution (A), and Pathophysiology (P). It provides a uniform language for describing the full spectrum of chronic venous disease.
definition.clinical: A comprehensive scoring system that helps clinicians describe exactly what venous disease a patient has, why they have it, where it is located, and what's wrong physiologically - enabling consistent communication and treatment planning.

core_concepts.explanation: Describes the visible and palpable signs of venous disease. C0: No visible signs. C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins. C2: Varicose veins. C3: Edema. C4a: Pigmentation or eczema. C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche. C5: Healed venous ulcer. C6: Active venous ulcer.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: The C class drives treatment decisions and prognostication. C4b-C6 represent severe disease requiring aggressive intervention.

core_concepts.explanation: Each clinical class is followed by 's' for symptomatic or 'a' for asymptomatic. Symptoms include aching, pain, heaviness, fatigue, itching, throbbing, or cramping attributable to venous disease.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: A patient with C2s has symptomatic varicose veins - important distinction for treatment indication.

core_concepts.explanation: Ec: Congenital (present from birth). Ep: Primary (cause unknown, presumed valve failure). Es: Secondary (post-thrombotic, post-traumatic). En: No venous cause identified.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Secondary (Es) disease from prior DVT has worse prognosis and different treatment implications than primary reflux.

core_concepts.explanation: As: Superficial veins (GSV, SSV, tributaries). Ap: Perforating veins. Ad: Deep veins. An: No venous location identified. Can be combined when multiple systems involved.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Guides intervention choice - superficial reflux is easily treatable; deep reflux is more challenging.

core_concepts.explanation: Pr: Reflux (valve incompetence). Po: Obstruction (venous narrowing or occlusion). Pro: Reflux and obstruction. Pn: No venous pathophysiology identified.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Distinguishes between reflux (most common, treatable by ablation) and obstruction (may require stenting or bypass).

core_concepts.explanation: Complete classification uses all components. Example: C4b,s,Ep,As,p,Pr - symptomatic lipodermatosclerosis from primary disease with superficial and perforator reflux.
core_concepts.clinical_significance: Full notation provides complete disease description but is cumbersome for routine use. Basic CEAP (C class only) is often sufficient.

C0.description: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease
C0.examples: Patient with leg symptoms but no physical findings
C0.significance: May have symptoms from reflux not yet manifest clinically

C1.significance: Often cosmetic concern; may indicate underlying reflux

C2.significance: May be symptomatic or asymptomatic; treatment indicated when symptomatic

C3.examples: Ankle swelling worse with standing, improved with elevation

C4a.significance: Skin changes indicate risk of progression to ulceration

C4b.examples: Indurated, woody skin; white atrophic areas with telangiectasias
C4b.significance: Severe skin damage; high risk of ulceration

C5.examples: Scar at gaiter region from prior ulcer
C5.significance: History of most severe manifestation; high recurrence risk

C6.examples: Open wound at medial malleolus with irregular edges
C6.significance: Most severe manifestation; requires aggressive treatment

utility.communication: Provides standardized language for describing venous disease
utility.research: Allows comparison across studies and centers

learning_objectives: Explain the Etiologic, Anatomic, and Pathophysiologic components
Construct a complete CEAP classification for a patient
Use CEAP to guide treatment decisions
key_takeaways: C classes: C1 spider veins → C6 active ulcer
Es (secondary/post-thrombotic) has worse prognosis than Ep (primary)
Basic CEAP (C class alone) is sufficient for most clinical use
